home.title: Learn Django
paragraphs: Django is a back-end server side web framework.
Django is free, open source and written in Python.
Django makes it easier to build web pages using Python.
Start learning Django now

sections.heading: Learning by Doing
paragraphs: In this tutorial you get a step by step guide on how to install and create a Django project. You will learn how to create a project where you can add, read, update or delete data.
You will learn how to make HTML Templates and use Django Template Tags to insert data within a HTML document.
You will learn how to work with QuerySets to extract, filter, and sort data from the database.
You will also learn how to set up a PostgreSQL database and how to deploy your Django project to the world.

sections.heading: What is Django?
paragraphs: Django is a Python framework that makes it easier to create web sites using Python.
Django takes care of the difficult stuff so that you can concentrate on building your web applications.

Django emphasizes reusability of components, also referred to as DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself), and comes with ready-to-use features like login system, database connection and CRUD operations (Create Read Update Delete).
Django is especially helpful for database driven websites.

sections.heading: How does Django Work?
paragraphs: Django follows the MVT design pattern (Model View Template).
Model - The data you want to present, usually data from a database.
View - A request handler that returns the relevant template and content - based on the request from the user.
Template - A text file (like an HTML file) containing the layout of the web page, with logic on how to display the data.

sections.heading: Model
paragraphs: The model provides data from the database.
In Django, the data is delivered as an Object Relational Mapping (ORM), which is a technique designed to make it easier to work with databases.
The most common way to extract data from a database is SQL. One problem with SQL is that you have to have a pretty good understanding of the database structure to be able to work with it.
Django, with ORM, makes it easier to communicate with the database, without having to write complex SQL statements.
The models are usually located in a file called models.py.

sections.heading: View
paragraphs: A view is a function or method that takes http requests as arguments, imports the relevant model(s), and finds out what data to send to the template, and returns the final result.
The views are usually located in a file called views.py.

sections.heading: Template
paragraphs: A template is a file where you describe how the result should be represented.
Templates are often .html files, with HTML code describing the layout of a web page, but it can also be in other file formats to present other results, but we will concentrate on .html files.
Django uses standard HTML to describe the layout, but uses Django tags to add logic:
The templates of an application is located in a folder named templates.

sections.heading: URLs
paragraphs: Django also provides a way to navigate around the different pages in a website.
When a user requests a URL, Django decides which view it will send it to.
This is done in a file called urls.py.

sections.heading: So, What is Going On?
paragraphs: When you have installed Django and created your first Django web application, and the browser requests the URL, this is basically what happens:
Django receives the URL, checks the urls.py file, and calls the view that matches the URL.
The view, located in views.py, checks for relevant models.
The models are imported from the models.py file.
The view then sends the data to a specified template in the template folder.
The template contains HTML and Django tags, and with the data it returns finished HTML content back to the browser.
Django can do a lot more than this, but this is basically what you will learn in this tutorial, and are the basic steps in a simple web application made with Django.

sections.heading: Django History
paragraphs: Django was invented by Lawrence Journal-World in 2003, to meet the short deadlines in the newspaper and at the same time meeting the demands of experienced web developers.
Initial release to the public was in July 2005.
Latest version of Django is 4.0.3 (March 2022).

sections.heading: What's Next?
paragraphs: We have a Django project!
The next step is to make an app in your project.
You cannot have a web page created with Django without an app.

sections.heading: What is an App?
paragraphs: An app is a web application that has a specific meaning in your project, like a home page, a contact form, or a members database.
In this tutorial we will create an app that allows us to list and register members in a database.

sections.heading: Create App
paragraphs: Use startapp to create a new Django app inside your project.
Stop the server before running the command if it is already running.

sections.heading: App Files
paragraphs: Django creates a folder for the app with important files like models.py, views.py, and admin.py.
The views.py file is used to handle requests and send responses.

sections.heading: What are Views?
paragraphs: Django views are Python functions that take http requests and return http response, like HTML documents.
Views are usually put in a file called views.py located in your app folder.

sections.heading: Simple View Example
paragraphs: A simple view returns a response back to the browser.
The name of the view does not have to be the same as the application.

sections.heading: How Views Work
paragraphs: To execute a view, it must be connected to a URL.
You will learn about URLs in the next chapter.

sections.heading: App URLs
paragraphs: Create a urls.py file in the same folder as views.py.
This file connects URLs to view functions.
sections.example:
from django.urls import path
from . import views

urlpatterns = [
    path('members/', views.members, name='members'),
]

sections.heading: Project URLs
paragraphs: You must also include the app URLs in the main project urls.py file.
This routes incoming requests to the correct app.
sections.example:
from django.contrib import admin
from django.urls import include, path

urlpatterns = [
    path('', include('members.urls')),
    path('admin/', admin.site.urls),
]

sections.heading: Run and Test
paragraphs: Start the server and open the URL in the browser.

sections.heading: Create Template

Create a templates folder inside your app and add an HTML file.

paragraphs: Load the template in the view and return it as a response.

sections.heading: Register App
paragraphs: Add your app name to INSTALLED_APPS in settings.py so Django recognizes it.

sections.heading: Run Project
paragraphs: Run migrations and start the server to see the template in the browser.

python manage.py migrate

sections.heading: What is a Model?
paragraphs: A Django model is a table in your database.
Models represent data as Python objects and map them to database tables.

sections.heading: Create Model
paragraphs: Define models in the models.py file inside your app.
Each model class becomes a table in the database.
sections.example:
from django.db import models

class Member(models.Model):
  firstname = models.CharField(max_length=255)
  lastname = models.CharField(max_length=255)

sections.heading: Database
paragraphs: Django uses SQLite by default.
The database file is named db.sqlite3 and is created automatically.

sections.heading: Migrations
paragraphs: After creating a model, you must generate and apply migrations to create the table.
sections.example:
python manage.py makemigrations members
python manage.py migrate

sections.heading: Auto ID
paragraphs: Django automatically adds an id field as the primary key for each table.

sections.heading: Open Shell
paragraphs: Use the Django shell to interact with the database.
The shell lets you run Python code inside your project.

sections.heading: View Data
paragraphs: Import the model and check existing records.
A QuerySet represents data from the database.

sections.heading: Insert Single Record
paragraphs: Create a model object and save it to the database.

sections.heading: Insert Multiple Records
paragraphs: You can insert many records by creating multiple objects and saving them in a loop.
sections.example:
member1 = Member(firstname='Tobias', lastname='Refsnes')
member2 = Member(firstname='Linus', lastname='Refsnes')
members_list = [member1, member2]

for x in members_list:
  x.save()

sections.heading: Get Record
paragraphs: Fetch an existing record from the database using a QuerySet.
sections.example:
from members.models import Member

x = Member.objects.all()[4]

sections.heading: Update Record
paragraphs: Change the field values of the object and save it.

sections.heading: Verify Update
paragraphs: Check the updated data using a QuerySet.

sections.heading: Get Record
paragraphs: Fetch the record you want to delete from the database.
sections.example:
from members.models import Member

x = Member.objects.all()[5]

sections.heading: Delete Record
paragraphs: Call the delete() method on the object.

sections.heading: Verify Deletion
paragraphs: Check the remaining records to confirm deletion.

sections.heading: Add Fields
paragraphs: To change the structure of a table, update the model class in models.py.
New fields must be added to the model definition.
sections.example:
class Member(models.Model):
  firstname = models.CharField(max_length=255)
  lastname = models.CharField(max_length=255)
  phone = models.IntegerField(null=True)
  joined_date = models.DateField(null=True)

sections.heading: Create Migration
paragraphs: After modifying a model, generate a migration to reflect the changes.

sections.heading: Apply Migration
paragraphs: Apply the migration to update the database schema.

sections.heading: Update Data
paragraphs: Insert values into the new fields using the Django shell.
sections.example:
from members.models import Member

x = Member.objects.all()[0]
x.phone = 5551234
x.joined_date = '2022-01-05'
x.save()

sections.heading: Create Template
paragraphs: Create an HTML template to display data from the model.
Use Django template tags to loop through data.
sections.example:
Members

    {% for x in mymembers %}
  • {{ x.firstname }} {{ x.lastname }}
    • {% endfor %}

sections.heading: Modify View
paragraphs: Fetch model data in the view and send it to the template.
The context dictionary passes data to the template.

sections.heading: Run Project
paragraphs: Start the server and open the members URL in the browser.

sections.heading: Details Template
paragraphs: Create a new template to show details of a single record.
Use template variables to display model fields.
sections.example:
{{ mymember.firstname }} {{ mymember.lastname }}

Phone: {{ mymember.phone }}

Member since: {{ mymember.joined_date }}

Back to Members

sections.heading: Add Link in List
paragraphs: Make each item in the list clickable using its id.

sections.heading: Create Details View
paragraphs: Create a new view that fetches a single record using its id.

sections.heading: Add URL Route
paragraphs: Map the details URL to the new view.

sections.heading: Master Template
paragraphs: A master template contains common HTML shared across multiple pages.
It uses Django block tags as placeholders.
sections.example:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <title>{% block title %}{% endblock %}</title>
</head>
<body>
  {% block content %}
  {% endblock %}
</body>
</html>

sections.heading: Extend Master
paragraphs: Other templates extend the master template using the extends tag.
They fill in the title and content blocks.

sections.heading: Why Use Master Template
paragraphs: It avoids repeating the same HTML in multiple templates.
Changes in the layout only need to be done in one place.

sections.heading: Main Template
paragraphs: Create a main landing page template for the root URL.
This page is shown when users visit the project root.

sections.heading: Main View
paragraphs: Create a view that loads and renders the main template.

sections.heading: Root URL
paragraphs: Map the root URL to the main view.

sections.heading: Link Back to Home
paragraphs: Add a link back to the main page from other pages.

sections.heading: What is a 404 Page?
paragraphs: A 404 error occurs when a user tries to access a page that does not exist.
Django shows a default 404 page when DEBUG is set to False.

sections.heading: Enable 404 Page
paragraphs: Set DEBUG to False and define allowed hosts in settings.py.

sections.heading: Customize 404 Page
paragraphs: Create a 404.html file in the templates folder to customize the error page.
sections.example:
Ooops!

I cannot find the file you requested!

sections.heading: Reset Debug
paragraphs: After testing, set DEBUG back to True for development.

sections.heading: Create Test View
paragraphs: A test view is used to safely experiment with Django features.
It renders a template with sample data.

sections.heading: Add URL Route
paragraphs: Map the testing URL to the new test view.

sections.heading: Create Test Template
paragraphs: Create a template to display test data.

sections.heading: What is Django Admin?
paragraphs: Django Admin is a built-in CRUD interface for managing your models.
CRUD stands for Create, Read, Update, Delete.

sections.heading: Run Admin Panel
paragraphs: Start the development server.
Open the admin URL in the browser.

sections.heading: Admin URL Mapping
paragraphs: The admin panel works because the admin route is defined in urls.py.
sections.example:
from django.contrib import admin
from django.urls import path

urlpatterns = [
  path('admin/', admin.site.urls),
]

sections.heading: Why Create User?
paragraphs: To access the Django Admin panel, a superuser account is required.

sections.heading: Create Superuser
paragraphs: Use the createsuperuser command to create an admin account.

sections.heading: Login to Admin
paragraphs: Start the server and login using the created credentials.

sections.heading: Important Note
paragraphs: By default, only built-in models like Users and Groups appear.
Custom models must be registered to appear in Admin.

sections.heading: Register Model
paragraphs: To show a model in the admin panel, it must be registered.
This is done in the admin.py file of the app.
sections.example:
from django.contrib import admin
from .models import Member

admin.site.register(Member)

sections.heading: Result
paragraphs: After registering, the model appears in the admin interface.
You can view and manage records through the UI.

sections.heading: Next Step
paragraphs: By default, objects show as 'Model object (id)'.
You can customize display fields in admin settings.

set-list-display.title: Set Fields to Display in Admin

sections.heading: Problem
paragraphs: By default, Django shows records as 'Model object (id)' in the admin list.
This is not very user-friendly.

sections.heading: Option 1: __str__ Method
paragraphs: Override the __str__ method in the model to control how objects are displayed.

sections.heading: Option 2: list_display
paragraphs: Use list_display in admin.py to show selected fields as columns.

sections.heading: Result
paragraphs: Admin list now shows readable values instead of object ids.
Multiple fields appear as table columns.

sections.heading: Edit Records
paragraphs: You can update existing records directly from the Django Admin panel.
Click any member to open the edit form.

sections.heading: Update Fields
paragraphs: Modify fields like joined_date and phone number.
Save the changes to update the database.

sections.heading: Result
paragraphs: All changes are immediately reflected in the database.
You can repeat this for all members.

sections.heading: Add New Record
paragraphs: You can add new records directly from the Django Admin panel.
Click the 'Add Member' button to open the form.

sections.heading: Fill Form
paragraphs: Enter values for all member fields.
Click Save to store the new record.

sections.heading: Result
paragraphs: The new member is immediately added to the database.
It appears in the admin list view.

sections.heading: Delete from List
paragraphs: You can delete members by selecting them from the list view.
Choose the action 'Delete selected members'.

sections.heading: Delete from Edit Page
paragraphs: You can also open a member and click the red DELETE button.

sections.heading: Result
paragraphs: The selected members are permanently removed from the database.

sections.heading: Render Variables
paragraphs: Use {{ variable }} to display values inside templates.

sections.heading: Send Variables from View
paragraphs: Create a context dictionary in the view.
Pass it to template.render(context, request).

sections.heading: Create Variables in Template
paragraphs: Use {% with %} to define variables directly in the template.
They exist until {% endwith %}.

sections.heading: Use Model Data
paragraphs: Fetch data from models in views.
Loop through data using {% for %} in templates.

sections.heading: What are Template Tags
paragraphs: Template tags allow programming logic inside HTML.
They are written using {% %} brackets.

sections.heading: Common Examples
paragraphs: Use {% if %} for conditions.
Use {% for %} for loops.

sections.heading: Purpose
paragraphs: Template tags let Django process logic on the server.
They generate dynamic HTML before sending to browser.

sections.heading: Important Tags
paragraphs: if, for, extends, block, include, url, with, csrf_token

sections.heading: Basic If
paragraphs: The if tag is used to execute code only when a condition is true.
It must always be closed using the endif tag.

sections.heading: Elif and Else
paragraphs: The elif tag is used to check another condition if the first one fails.
The else tag executes when none of the conditions are true.

sections.heading: Comparison Operators
paragraphs: == checks if two values are equal.
!= checks if two values are not equal.
<, <=, >, >= are used for numeric comparisons.

sections.heading: Logical Operators
paragraphs: and returns true when all conditions are true.
or returns true when at least one condition is true.

sections.heading: Membership
paragraphs: The in keyword checks if a value exists inside a list or object.
The not in keyword checks if a value does not exist.

sections.heading: Identity
paragraphs: The is keyword checks if two variables point to the same object.
The is not keyword checks if two variables are different objects.

sections.heading: Truth Check
paragraphs: You can directly test a variable without comparison.
If the variable is not empty or false, the condition runs.

sections.heading: Basic List Loop
paragraphs: Use {% for %} to loop through a list.
End every loop with {% endfor %}.

sections.heading: Loop Through Model Data
paragraphs: You can loop through objects fetched from a Django model.

sections.heading: Loop With Index
paragraphs: Use forloop.counter to get the current index.

sections.heading: Reverse Loop
paragraphs: Use reversed keyword to loop in reverse order.

sections.heading: Empty List Handling
paragraphs: Use {% empty %} to handle empty lists safely.

sections.heading: First and Last Check
paragraphs: forloop.first and forloop.last help in UI logic.

sections.heading: Nested Loop
paragraphs: You can nest for loops for complex data structures.

sections.heading: What is Django?
paragraphs: Django is a high-level Python web framework that encourages rapid development.
It follows the MVT (Model View Template) design pattern.
code: # Example of a simple Django View

sections.heading: The MVT Pattern
paragraphs: Model: The data handler (Database).
View: The logic handler (Processes requests).
Template: The presentation handler (HTML).

sections.heading: Creation
paragraphs: Use the venv module to create an isolated environment named 'myworld'.

sections.heading: Activation
paragraphs: You must activate the environment before installing Django.
